awd_titl_txt: I-Corps:  Megaton carbon capture technology for point-source emitters
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is the development of a large-scale carbon capture technology. Current commercial large-scale carbon capture technologies (amine scrubbing and calcium looping) have a high operational cost of $50/ton or higher. Emerging carbon capture technologies such as metal organic framework and composite sorbent generally do not possess the mechanical properties such as crush resistance required for megaton-scale deployment. The proposed technology is designed to achieve megaton-scale carbon capture with an estimated operational cost of $30/ton. This is a deep technology innovation that works with an industrially-proven subscription model. The proposed technology will reduce the emissions when the powerplant does not already have a carbon capture unit, and reduce the cost if the power plant already has an existing carbon capture unit.

This I-Corps project is based on the development of development of granular metal carbonate (GMC) as a single-ingredient solid adsorbent for point-source carbon dioxide (CO2) capture. Abrased GMC particles are recycled through granulation. The recyclability of GMC limits the waste of sorbent while maintaining a low heat capacity, achieving the lowest cost per ton of CO2 captured. The proposed technology may remove >90% of the CO2 from flue gases containing 5%-40% CO2 in humid and dry environments. This approach leverages the high CO2 concentration in the flue gas (>5%) and excess heat to achieve economical carbon capture with a small footprint (<10% of the plant’s surface area).

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
This NSF I-CORP award focused on the development of a commercial process to capture carbon dioxide at megaton scale. The process is based on an earlier laboratory scale system developed at Caltech. In this NSF-supported work, the goal is to design a system that can be installed at sites that emit carbon dioxide, such as fossil-fuel power plants, cement, steel, and fertilizer production plants. The proposed technology is on target to achieve commercial scale carbon capture at an operational cost below that of the current market.

Intellectual merit: The I-CORP work focused on outreach to more than 100 potential customers, partners, and investors who are engaged in carbon capture utilization and storage. The team included an entrepreneurial lead, a technical lead, and an industrial mentor. Together, the team identified industrial point source emitters, specifically gas-fired power plants as the ultimate target market of the technology. The interviews also revealed how the users would like to see the technology incorporated into their plants. The feedback highlighted the need for a system that is similar to an independent post-emission control device; importantly, the users emphasized that any carbon capture system could not decrease the performance of the host plant. This feedback sets the framework for the development of the next generation prototype.

Broader impacts: The development of a new commercial technology for carbon capture will have a significant impact on industrial emitters of carbon dioxide, enabling companies to reach their carbon reduction goals without negatively impacting the performance of their plant or significantly increasing the cost of their process.
